questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the minimum age requirements for employing children in factories as per the Factories Act?

choices.text: Guaranteed employment for under 14-year-olds from below-poverty-line families in factories.
No employment for under 18-year-olds in factories.
Under 14-year-olds can be employed only in non-hazardous factory roles.
15-18 year olds need a fitness certificate for factory work from a certified surgeon

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 15-18-year-olds need a fitness certificate for factory work from a certified surgeon

Explanation:

Children between 15-18 years of age require a certificate of fitness from a certified surgeon to be employed in factories as per the Factory Act.

Factory Act

Definition

An establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used or 20 or more workers where power is not used.

Applicability

Applies to all of India and covers all factories, including perennial and seasonal factories.

Age Restrictions

(Option A, B and D)
  • Prohibits employment of children below 14 years of age.
  • 15-18 year olds need fitness certificate for factory work from a certified surgeon

Hours of Work
  • Work limited to 48 hours/week or 9 hours/day; max 60 hours/week with overtime.
  • Adolescents: max 4.5 hours/day.
  • Women and adolescents: work hours 6 am to 7 pm.

Leave
  • Grants 1 day of leave per 15 days of work for adolescents
  • 1 day per 30 days of work for adults.
  • Permits accumulation of leaves up to 40 days for adolescents and 30 days for adults.

Health & Safety
  • Mandates a minimum of 500 cubic feet of space per worker.
  • Requires 1 safety officer per 1000 workers.

Welfare

Stipulates 1 welfare officer per 500 workers, 1 canteen per 250 workers, and 1 crèche per 30 women workers.

questions.text: Which statement regarding the administration of the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Act is incorrect?

choices.text: ESI Corporation administers the ESI Scheme
Union Minister for Labour is Chairman of the ESI Corporation.
The Director General of Health Services heads the Medical Benefit Council.
ESI Corporation functions under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) ESI Corporation functions under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.

Explanation:

The Employees' State Insurance Corporation (ESIC) functions autonomously under the Ministry of Labour and Employment.

 

ESI (Employees State Insurance) Act

Year

1948

Applicability

Factories
  • Applies to all non-seasonal factories employing 10 or more persons in implemented areas, regardless of power usage.
  • Excludes railways, defense, and mines.

Other Establishments
  • Covers shops, hotels and restaurants, cinemas and theaters, road-motor transport establishments, and newspaper establishments.

Employee Eligibility
  • Employees earning up to Rs. 21,000 per month are eligible for benefits. This includes manual, clerical, supervisory, and technical employees.

Administration (Option D)
  • Managed by the autonomous Employees' State Insurance Corporation (ESIC).
  • ESIC chairman: The Union Minister for Labour
  • The Secretary to the Government of India, Ministry of Labour, is the Vice-Chairman.

Contribution Rates

Employer

3.25% of the total wage bill.

Employee

0.75% of their wages.

Exemption

Employees earning less than Rs 176 per day are exempt from contributing.

questions.text: Which of the following benefits is not offered under the ESI Act?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Paid Vacation Time

Explanation:

Paid vacation time is not a benefit under the ESI Act.

Benefits of ESI(Employees State Insurance) Act.

Medical Benefit

Provides "full medical care," including hospitalization at no cost to insured individuals & families in cases of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.

Sickness Benefit

Provides 70% of average daily wages in cash during medical leave for a maximum of 91 days within 365 days, as certified by the Insurance Medical Officer/Practitioner.

Extended Sickness Benefit

Extended coverage for long-term diseases beyond 91 days; 34 diseases covered if employed for two years.

Extended sickness benefit is paid at 80% of the insured person's wages.

Enhanced Sickness Benefit
  • Cash benefits (100% wages) for sterilisation procedures:
    • 14 days for tubectomy (women),
    • 7 days for vasectomy (men).

Maternity Benefit
  • Cash payments for childbirth, miscarriage, or pregnancy-related sickness:
    • 26 weeks for childbirth,
    • 6 weeks for miscarriage, and
    • 40 days for pregnancy-related sickness.
  • Paid at 100% of the insured woman's average daily wages.

Disablement Benefit
  • Temporary Disablement Benefit (TDB):
    • 90% of wages paid from day one for temporary employment injury, until recovery.
  • Permanent Disablement Benefit (PDB):
    • 90% of wages paid monthly for life, based on certified loss of earning capacity.

Dependent's Benefit
  • Dependents receive 90% of the deceased's (due to employment injuries) wages as a shared pension, eligible until age 18 or earlier for married daughters.
  • If daughter marries before 18 the benefit is withdrawn

Funeral Expenses

(Option C)

Offers a cash payment up to Rs. 15,000 to cover funeral expenses upon the death of an insured individual.

Rehabilitation

(Option D)
  • Insured individuals and their families are entitled to continued medical treatment even after permanent disablement or retirement.
  • They have to pay a nominal fee of Rs.10 per month to avail this benefit.
  • Rehabilitation allowance of Rs.15,000 granted.

Unemployment allowance

(Option A)

For eligible employees due to factory closure or retrenchment: 50% of wage for up to two years.

questions.text: Which of the following benefits offered under the ESI Act provides coverage for 26 weeks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Maternity benefit for confinement

Explanation:

  • Maternity Benefit under ESI Act
    1. Payable for up to 26 weeks (6 months) for 2 surviving children
    2. Paid at 100% of insured woman's average daily wages
    3. Max 8 weeks can be availed before expected date of confinement
  • Miscarriage or MTP
    1. 6 weeks (42 days) of maternity benefit from date after miscarriage/MTP
    2. Paid at 100% of insured woman's average daily wages
  • Sickness from Pregnancy, Confinement, Premature Birth
    1. Up to 4 weeks of maternity benefit
    2. Paid at 100% of insured woman's average daily wages

 

(Option A) The ESI Act provides sickness benefits for a maximum period of 91 days in any continuous period of 365 days.

(Option C) Temporary disablement benefit is paid for the duration the temporary disability lasts.

(Option D) Extended sickness benefit is payable for a maximum period of two years.

questions.text: Which of the following schemes is most closely related to providing unemployment relief to eligible individuals who have lost their jobs in specific circumstances?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Atal Beemit Vyakti Kalyan Yojana

Explanation:

 

Scheme

Description

Key Features

Atal Beemit Vyakti Kalyan Yojana
  • Provides financial assistance to employees covered under the ESI Act, 1948, who become unemployed.
  • Offers relief payment for up to 90 days, once in a lifetime.
  • The relief payment is 50% of the employee's wages.
  • To be eligible, the insured person must have been employed for at least two years and contributed for at least 78 days.

Abhiyan Indra Dhanush

(Option C)
  • Aims to enhance hygiene and cleanliness in ESIC hospitals.
  • Implements a VIBGYOR colour-coded pattern for changing bed sheets.

MGNREGA (Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act)

(Option D)
  • Guarantees 100 days of paid work to rural households.
  • Provides wage employment to households below the poverty line who are willing to perform unskilled manual labor.
  • Employment must be provided within 15 days of application; otherwise, the individual is entitled to unemployment allowance

questions.text: Which of the following chemicals was released during the Bhopal gas tragedy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Methyl isocyanate
Explanation:
The Bhopal gas tragedy is one of the worst man-made disasters involved in the accidental leak of Methyl isocyanate (MIC) (Option C) in the Union Carbide Pesticide plant in 1984.

It is a point source single exposure epidemic.

Clinical features of MIC poisoning:

  • Toxicity develops within 1-4 hours of exposure.
  • Symptoms: Cough, dyspnea, chest pain, lacrimation, eyelid swelling and unconsciousness.
  • These symptoms progress over next 24-72 hours and may lead to acute lung injury, cardiac arrest and death

 

(Options A & D) Strontium and Cesium are chemicals that leaked from nuclear accidents such as Fukushima.

(Option B) Sarin, an organophosphate, used in biochemical warfare as a nerve agent. It leads to a cholinergic crisis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence in a disaster management cycle?

choices.text: Disaster impact → Response → Rehabilitation → Reconstruction → Mitigation → Preparedness
Disaster impact → Mitigation → Preparedness → Response → Rehabilitation → Reconstruction
Disaster impact → Response → Rehabilitation → Reconstruction → Preparedness → Mitigation
Disaster impact → Rehabilitation → Reconstruction → Response → Mitigation → Preparedness

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Disaster impact→Response→Rehabilitation→Reconstruction→Mitigation→Preparedness
Explanation:
Disaster management is a systematic approach using decisions, organizations to implement policies, strategies to lessen the impact of natural or man-made hazards.

Disaster management cycle:

The three fundamental aspects of disaster management:

  1. Disaster impact: Involves disaster response and relief.
  2. Disaster preparedness: It is the proper equipment of the country to manage disasters.
  3. Disaster mitigation: Preventing the hazard from becoming a disaster.

questions.text: During a disaster, a patient is suffering from a closed femur fracture with stable vital signs and another patient with a penetrating chest wound with respiratory distress. Which of the following are the colour coding given to the patients respectively based on triage principle?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Yellow and Red
 

Explanation:
The first patient, with a closed femur fracture and stable vitals, is triaged as YELLOW, requiring assistance within 24 hours. The second patient, in respiratory distress, necessitates immediate resuscitation and is triaged as RED.

Triage:

During a disaster, the quantity and severity of injuries overwhelm the operative capacity of the health facilities. Triage involves rapidly organizing the injured individuals based on the severity of their injuries and survival with prompt interventions.

During triage, tagging should be done to each individual, including:

  1. Name
  2. Age
  3. Place of origin
  4. Triage category
  5. Diagnosis and
  6. Initial treatment.

Color coding in triage:

 

Types of triage:

Reverse triage:

  • Used in surge (bed scarcity) and during wars.
  • Priority: Green→Yellow→Red.

Simple triage and Rapid Treatment (START):

  • Done in remote or inaccessible areas.
  • Laymen can start doing triage before rescue teams reach.

questions.text: Following an earthquake, which of the following is the most effective step to manage infectious diseases?

choices.text: Mass vaccination against all infectious agents
Ensure thorough water chlorination and adequate sanitation

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Ensure thorough water chlorination and adequate sanitation
Explanation:
Epidemiological Survey and Disease Control:

Post-disaster:

Due to

Disease

Poor sanitation and overcrowding
  • Acute respiratory diseases
  • Gastrointestinal diseases (most common)

Displacement of animals
  • Zoonotic diseases

Floods
  • Leptospirosis and rickettsia
  • The most common vitamin deficiency post-disaster is Vitamin A deficiency.
  • Contamination of the water supply and displacement of the population are the most common causes of communicable diseases.
  • Therefore, ensuring a safe water supply with chlorination and proper sanitation is the most effective step to decrease the risk of infectious diseases (option C).

 

Vaccination protocol:

  • All vaccines except for measles are contraindicated post-disaster (option A).
  • Multidose vaccines, such as typhoid and cholera vaccines, have poor compliance and have not yet proven to be effective as a large-scale public health measure.
  • The most common post-disaster outbreak is measles. For this reason, measles vaccines can be given within three days of exposure since the time taken for antibodies to form is less than the natural incubation period of the disease.
  • Tetanus vaccine is given based on previous vaccinations and severity of injury.
  • Vaccines for healthcare workers: Cholera, Typhoid, Tetanus, Hep B.

Meticulous antibiotic supply requires additional persons who can be helpful in other areas of disaster, and identifying infected and uninfected individuals is a time-consuming process. (Option B)

Following a disaster, there will be disruption of properties, displacement of people, monetary restrictions, limited personnel and poor sanitation. For these reasons, isolating infected people is difficult.(Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding post-disaster rehabilitation and accommodation?

choices.text: 0.5 gm chlorine tablet is sufficient for 20 liters of water
Distance between water point and latrine should be 100 mts
Number of people per water point should be 150

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D
Explanation:
Post-disaster rehabilitation:

  • Returning to pre-disaster conditions.

Water supply
  • Safe water supply with chlorination.
  • Residual chlorine levels should be >0.7 mg/L for 1 hour contact period (Option A).
  • 0.5 mg chlorine tablets sufficient for 20 L water (Option B).

Food and Vector control
  • Safe food should be ensured
  • To protect from vector-borne diseases, rodenticides like zinc phosphide must be sprayed.
  • Indoor residual sprays must be used for mosquitoes and sandflies.

Accommodation guidelines
  • Per person shelter space: 3.4 square meters
  • Number of people per water point: 250 (option D)
  • Distance to water point: 150 meters
  • Number of people per latrine: 20
  • Distance to latrine: 30 meters
  • Distance between water point and latrine: 100 mts (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of disaster mitigation according to the provided information?

choices.text: Improved building codes for earthquake-resistant structures
Flood mitigation codes for dam resistance

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Developing communication and warning systems
Explanation:
Developing communication and warning systems because this component is part of disaster preparedness, not disaster mitigation. This is a part of disaster preparedness activities, which aim to manage and respond to emergencies effectively.

Disaster Mitigation:

  • Prevents hazards from becoming disasters.
  • Mitigation is a crucial component of disaster preparedness. It aims to lessen the potential impact of hazards through long-term development activities.
    1. Disaster Mitigation in Health Sector: Focuses on safeguarding health facilities and public services like water and sanitation to prevent economic strain during post-disaster rehabilitation.
    2. Importance of Safe Water and Sanitation: Vital for disaster mitigation in health, as contamination or disruption of water supplies can lead to social upheaval and costly rehabilitation efforts.
    3. Structural Mitigation Measures: For example, Utilizing engineering modalities to prevent hazards,
      • Proper land use (option A)
      • Improved building codes for earthquake-resistant structures (option B)
      • Flood mitigation codes for dam resistance (option D)
    4. Relationship to Disaster Management Cycle: Represents a proactive approach within disaster management, complementing preparedness and response activities to minimize disaster impacts.
  • Reduces vulnerability to disasters and strengthens the capacity to manage emergencies effectively.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a key activity of disaster preparedness?

choices.text: Risk assessment to identify specific hazards
Securing financial and logistical resources for preparedness and response
Public education programs to raise awareness about disaster risks and responses

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Enforcing disaster-resistant building codes
Explanation:
Enforcing disaster-resistant building codes is a mitigation measure because it involves implementing measures that prevent hazards from turning into disasters.

Disaster Preparedness

Aims to reduce the impact of hazards through long-term development.

Key Activities:

  • Risk assessment to identify specific hazards (Option A)
  • Establishing standards and regulations for construction and land use
  • Developing communication, information, and warning systems for timely alerts
  • Organizing and coordinating response mechanisms, including:
    1. Training and equipping emergency personnel
    2. Establishing evacuation procedures
    3. Stockpiling essential supplies
  • Securing financial and logistical resources for preparedness and response (Option B)
  • Public education programs to raise awareness about disaster risks and responses (Option C)
  • Collaboration with news media for effective information dissemination during emergencies
  • Conducting disaster simulation exercises to test and improve response mechanisms

Integration of Mitigation Measures

Disaster mitigation in disaster preparedness aims to minimize hazard impacts through proactive development efforts, enhancing resilience and emergency management capabilities.

Empowers local individuals as first responders.

Effective when communities manage internal and external assistance programs.

Multi-Sectoral Approach

Involves collaboration among government agencies, NGOs, communities, and individuals.

Ensures a comprehensive and coordinated response to mitigate disaster risks and enhance resilience.

questions.text: Which agency was established by the Disaster Management Act (2005) to oversee disaster management at the national level in India?
questions.solution:
Correct answer:  C) National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA)
Explanation:
The NDMA, established by the Disaster Management Act (2005), prepares national-level disaster management plans and coordinates disaster management efforts across India. It plays a key role in disaster response and mitigation at the national level.

Disaster Management Act (2005):

  • Established the National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) and State Disaster Management Authorities (SDMAs).
  • Provides a legal framework for disaster management in India.

National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA):

  • Prepares national-level disaster management plans and oversees their execution.
  • Key agency for disaster management coordination in India.

National Institute of Disaster Management: (Option B)

  • Located in New Delhi, focuses on capacity building, training, and research.
  • Aims to strengthen national disaster response capabilities.

Role of State Governments:

  • Direct responsibility for executing relief efforts post-disaster.
  • Supported by the Union government through the Calamity Relief Fund (3:1 contribution ratio).

Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA): (Option A)

  • Nodal ministry for overall coordination of disaster management.
  • Chaired by the Prime Minister, oversees disaster response at the national level.

National Crisis Management Committee (NCMC) and Cabinet Committee on Security (CCS):

  • Involved in high-level decision-making for disaster management in India.

Emergency Medical Relief Wing: (Option D)

  • Operates under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, coordinates health-related activities during disasters.
